column4: I've got an application that's pretty sensitive to kernel and package changes, but need to deploy it over time to a range of machines.  Is there a way I can "snapshot" or create some automated log so that when I install on newer machines it doesn't grab the wrong updates?  I need particular versions of the kernel etc
what application? and why is it so dependent on the kernel version (most dependencies on kernel versions are >=, not =)
given the circumstances you should probably package your drivers and the kernel to go with them for your deployments
so just write a script to downgrade the kernel to the right level?
no, build a debian package with the kernel you need
ok, I'll look into what it takes to build a deb file, never gone it
ahh it just uses an analog devices ADC, the rest is in software
at least the pci version is :P
I imagine they're all the same, they seem to be good at repackaging for different form factors
you should see if you can get them to split it up and open source it, it's not really remarkable, the hard part is done in dumb hardware
we've been asking and asking, I have a dev heading over there next week where I hope we can ask some more
does the package linux-image exist anymore?  This might be useful enough for me to just install it instead of a custom kernel
linux-image is a skeleton package that depends on others

you can crib the old debdiff to build the kernel version you want to stick with; i only suggested building your own because eventually ubuntu will stop building that version, if they haven't already; it'd just be like using the version in the archive
they just don't keep the old kernel version packages around?
the same goes for any package really
yea, fair enough, I thought they might be different for kernels
